lg.l: Hevâ ‘arāyis-i gülzāre oldı çihre-güşā
Bahār gülşene geydürdi hülle-yi ḥażrā
lg.note: The air has unveiled the faces of the brides of the rose garden; Spring has clad the garden in a green, heavenly robe.

lg.l: Çemen eyāletine oldı naṣb ḫusrev gül
Hevāya ebr ṣıfat ḥükmin étmege icrā
lg.note: The rose, the sovereign, has been appointed to the province of the meadow to execute his decrees in the air, like a cloud.

lg.l: Yazıldı sebze-yi nev-ḫīzden ḫaṭṭ-ı aḥkām
Çekildi sāye-yi maṭbū‘-ı servden ṭuğrā
lg.note: The decree of laws was written by the newly sprouted greenery, and the royal seal (tughra) was drawn by the graceful shadow of the cypress.
Metaphorical use of Ottoman bureaucratic terminology ("hatt-ı ahkam", "tughra") to describe nature.

lg.l: Şarīr-i āb-ı revān u ṣafīr-i murġ-ı çemen
Nükāt-ı tehniye-yi maḳdem étdiler inşā
lg.note: The murmur of flowing water and the whistle of the meadow birds composed nuances of congratulations for this arrival.

lg.l: Zebān-ı sūsen-i āzād u sebze-yi nev-ḫīz
Şenā-yı rif‘at u iclāle oldılar gūyā
lg.note: The tongue of the free lily and the new greenery became eloquent in praising highness and majesty.

lg.l: Şaḳāyıḳ alnı zemīn-būsdan olup mecrūḥ
Benefşe ḳāmeti oldı tevāżu‘ ile dü-tā
lg.note: The forehead of the anemone was wounded from kissing the ground, and the stature of the violet became doubled with humility.

lg.l: Müretteb eyledi bir bezm gülşen içre bahār
Ki vėrdi zevḳ-ı temāşāsı neş’e-yi ṣahbā
lg.note: Spring arranged a banquet within the rose garden; the pleasure of watching it gave the joy of red wine.

lg.l: ‘Anādil étdi beyān-ı merātib-i naġamāt
Ḳamārī oldı terāne-keş ü sürūd-serā
lg.note: The nightingales explained the degrees of melodies, and the turtledove became the singer and the composer of tunes.

lg.l: Şadā-yı murġ bıraḫdı büzürg ü küçege şevḳ
Sürūd-ı nāyla ‘uşşāḳa ḥāṣıl oldı nevā
lg.note: The sound of the birds sent a longing to the great and the small; with the melody of the reed-flute, a tune was born for the lovers.

lg.l: Bilindi ġoncede gül bergi żāhir olmaġla
Ki ġonce başına yağdırdı jāle seng-i cefā
lg.note: It became known as the rose petals appeared in the bud; for the dew rained stones of torment upon the bud’s head.

lg.l: Cerāḥat olmasa a‘żāda żāhir olmaz ḳan
Tereşşuḥ eylemez elbette sınmadın mīnā
lg.note: Unless there is a wound, blood does not appear on the limbs; the wine-glass does not leak, of course, until it is broken.

lg.l: Hümāy-veş varaḳ-ı yāsemīn ü berg-i semen
Uçup hevāya gülistāna düşdi żıll-ı hümā
lg.note: Like the Huma bird, the jasmine petals and the jasmine leaves flew into the air, and the shadow of the Huma fell upon the rose garden.

lg.l: Bahār tāciri mışr-ı çemen ġanīlerine
Bıraḫdı Yūsuf-ı gül ‘arż eyleyüp ġavġā
lg.note: The merchant of Spring left the "Joseph of the Rose" to the wealthy of the Meadow-Egypt, causing a great stir.
Reference to the Quranic story of Joseph (Yusuf) and Egypt (Misr).

lg.l: Bu zevḳ ṣaldı Züleyḫā-yı lāleye bir şevḳ
Ki la‘l ü müşg töküp vėrdi ağırınca bahā
lg.note: This delight sent a passion to the "Zuleika of the Tulip," who gave a price as heavy as itself by pouring rubies and musk.

lg.l: Ḥadīḳa taḥta-yı ta‘līm olup reyāḥīnden
Yazıldı mühmel ü mu‘cem aña ḥurūf-ı hecā
lg.note: The garden became a tablet of instruction, and from the aromatic plants, the dotted and undotted letters of the alphabet were written upon it.

lg.l: Müzeyyen eyledi evrāḳ-ı lāleyi şebnem
Ḥurūf-ı lālede olmaz egerçi noḳṭa revā
lg.note: The dew adorned the leaves of the tulip, even though dots are not permissible on the letters of the "tulip" (in calligraphy).
Calligraphic allusion: The word 'Lale' (Tulip) in Arabic script does not contain dotted letters.

lg.l: Götürdi şebnemi ezhārdan ḥarāret-i mihr
Şükūfe noḳṭaların gerçi ḥükm éder imlā
lg.note: The heat of the sun removed the dew from the flowers, even though orthography governs the dots of the blossoms.

lg.l: Debīr-i bād vėrüp ṭıfl-ı ‘andelībe sabaḳ
Götürdi çihre-yi ezhārdan niḳāb-ı ḫafā
lg.note: The scribe of the wind gave a lesson to the child-nightingale and removed the veil of secrecy from the face of the flowers.

lg.l: Ḳamu dıraḫt bulup ref‘-i istiḳāmet-i ḥāl
Şükūfe ḥamli ile kesr buldılar illā
lg.note: All the trees found an elevation in their condition, but they were bent by the burden of their blossoms.

lg.l: Nihāl-i bī-bedel-i serv kim ḳalup manṣūb
Şebāt-ı ḥāl ile anlerden oldı müsteşnā
lg.note: Except for the peerless sapling of the cypress, which, remaining fixed, was excluded from them by its steadfastness.

lg.l: Şadā-yı seyl çeker medd-i muttaṣıl ya‘nī
Ki medd-i muttaṣıl ile olur ḳırā’at-ı mā
lg.note: The sound of the flood draws a "continuous extension"; that is, the recitation of "Water" occurs with that continuous extension.
Linguistic and Tajwid allusion: "Medd-i muttasıl" is a rule of Quranic recitation regarding vowel extension.

lg.l: Görindi hey’et-i āb-ı revānda şekl-i ḥabāb
Şübūta yėtdi şebāt-ı nücūm u seyr-i semā
lg.note: The shape of bubbles appeared in the form of flowing water; thus, the permanence of the stars and the movement of the heavens were proven.

lg.l: Ḥuṭūṭ-ı muḫtelif ü müstaḳīmi enhāruñ
Çemende ṣaldı zevāyā-yı gūne gūne binā
lg.note: The various and straight lines of the rivers built diverse corners in the meadow.
Geometry metaphor: Rivers are likened to lines (hutut) and angles (zevaya) in a architectural layout.

lg.l: Ri‘āyet-i ṭuruḳ-ı müstaḳīmden nėçe kim
Olur ḥuṣūl-i maḳāmāt-ı cennetü’l-me’vā
lg.note: Just as by following the straight paths, one attains the stations of the Paradise of Abode.

lg.l: Hevâ-yı bāġdan étdüm bu ḥikmeti ma‘lūm
Ki i‘tidāldedür ṣıḥḥat-ı ḥavāss u ḳuvā
lg.note: From the air of the garden, I have learned this wisdom: that the health of senses and faculties lies in moderation.

lg.l: Bahār gülşeni ezhārla görüp memlū
Yaḳīnüm oldı ki mümkün degül vücūd-ı ḫalā
lg.note: Seeing the garden of spring filled with blossoms, I became certain that a vacuum in existence is impossible.
Natural philosophy: A reference to the ancient debate on "horror vacui" (nature abhors a vacuum).

lg.l: Naẓarda olmaġ ile ṣubḥ u şām ġonce vü gül
Bedīhī oldı kemāl ehline ḥuṣūl-i ṣafā
lg.note: By keeping the bud and the rose in sight morning and evening, the attainment of purity became self-evident to the people of perfection.

lg.l: Netīce sālibe olmaḳ ḫilāf-ı ‘ādetdür
Olınca mūcib-i ṣuġrāya müttefiḳ kübrā
lg.note: It is contrary to the norm for the conclusion to be negative when the major premise agrees with the affirmative minor premise.
Aristotelian Logic: Reference to the structure of syllogisms (Sughra, Kubra, Natica).

lg.l: Żamīr-i gül-büne gül rengi ṣaldı āteş-i bīm
Ki ḥumre ḳana olur nefs evinde rāh-nümā
lg.note: The color of the rose cast a fire of fear into the heart of the rose-bush; for redness is a guide to blood in the house of the self.

lg.l: Gül āteş üzere ḳılur ‘ıḳd-ı zühre-yi şebnem
Tedārik-i ḳamer ü şems éder ṣabāḥ u mesā
lg.note: The rose forms a knot of the "Venus of dew" over the fire; it prepares the moon and the sun morning and evening.

lg.l: Bu kīmiyā sebebinden ‘aceb midür olsa
Elinde dāne-yi erzen meşābesinde ṭılā
lg.note: Because of this alchemy, is it a wonder if gold, in his hand, becomes like a grain of millet?
Alchemy allusion: The poet contrasts spiritual value with material gold.

lg.l: Şükūfe sīmine farż eyledi ḫurūc-ı zekāt
Medār-ı ḥavl u bülūġ niṣāb ü istinmā
lg.note: He made the distribution of alms obligatory upon the silver of the blossoms; based on the criteria of the passing year, maturity, and growth.
Islamic Jurisprudence (Fiqh): Allusion to the conditions of Zakat (wealth tax).

lg.l: Ḥuṭūṭ-ı muḫtelif ü müstaḳīmi enhāruñ
Çemende ṣaldı zevāyā-yı gūne gūne binā
lg.note: The various and straight lines of the rivers built diverse corners in the meadow.

lg.l: Bahārdan ten-i gül-bünde eyleyüp heyecān
Ḥarāret-i demevī ḳıldı ġuddeler peydā
lg.note: Due to spring, excitement rose in the body of the rose-bush, and the sanguine heat caused glands (buds) to appear.

lg.l: Boyandı ḳanı ile ṣafḥa-yı çemen gül gül
Meger ki faṣlına ḥükm eylemiş ṭabīb-i hevā
lg.note: The page of the meadow was stained rose-red with its blood; perhaps the physician of the air ordered a bloodletting.
Traditional Medicine: "Fasl" refers to the medical practice of phlebotomy (bloodletting).

lg.l: Ḥibāl-i siḥre dönüp cünbiş-i cedāvil-i āb
Kelīm-i serv aña ‘aksdin bıraḫdı ‘aṣā
lg.note: The movement of the water streams turned into the ropes of magic; the Moses of the cypress cast his staff against them through its reflection.

lg.l: Olup terennüm-i bülbül ‘azāyim-i teshīr
Çemen perīlerine lāzım oldı ‘arż-ı liḳā
lg.note: As the nightingale's song became a spell of subjugation, it became necessary for the fairies of the meadow to show their faces.

lg.l: Bisāṭ-ı gülşene dün eyledüm güzer ki demi
Ḳılam neẓāre-yi āşār-ı ḳudret-i mevlā
lg.note: Yesterday I passed through the carpet of the rose garden so that for a moment I might observe the traces of the Lord's power.

lg.l: ‘Aceb nizā‘ ile gördüm çemen żarīflerin
Ta‘aṣṣub ile ḳamu sālik-i ṭarīḳ-ı ḫatā
lg.note: With wonder, I saw the wits of the meadow in such a dispute; through prejudice, they were all travelers on the path of error.

lg.l: Ḳamu gümān ile müsted‘ī-yi ṭarīḳ-ı necāt
Velī ḳamusına bāṭıl delīl-i istid‘ā
lg.note: All of them, based on mere suspicion, were seekers of the path of salvation; but for all of them, the evidence of their plea was false.

lg.l: Şanup şükūfe mebādī ṣunūf-ı eşcārı
Ḳılurdı baḥş ki cā’iz ta‘addüd-i ḳudemā
lg.note: Regarding the blossoms as the principles of the classes of trees, they were debating that the multiplicity of "eternal beings" is permissible.
Theological-Philosophy: A debate on the nature of 'eternal beings' (Qudema) and the First Cause.

lg.l: Vėrüp teselsüle ḳuvvet ṭabī‘at-ı kec-i āb
Olurdı nāfī-yi is̱bāt-ı ‘illet-i ūlā
lg.note: The crooked nature of the water, giving strength to infinite regression, was denying the proof of the "First Cause."
Philosophy: "Illet-i Ula" refers to the Aristotelian First Cause.

lg.l: Ḫayāl-i maḥż şanup kāyinātı nergis-i mest
Ḳılurdı cehl ile nefy-i ḥaḳāyıḳ-ı eşyā
lg.note: The intoxicated narcissus, thinking the universe to be a pure illusion, was denying the reality of things out of ignorance.

lg.l: Bulmadı rāh-ı necāt bülbül-i kāfir-nihād
Secde-yi gül ile umup teshīr-i ḥükm-i Hudā
lg.note: The infidel-natured nightingale would prostrate before the rose; hoping for salvation through the worship of an idol.

lg.l: Fark étdi saba bu fesādı vėrdi tenbīh
Dédi ey cemā‘at-ı perīşān rāh-ı hüdāya gel
lg.note: The breeze became aware of that corruption and forbade it, saying: "O scattered crowd, hold to the path of guidance!"

lg.l: Bu kār-ḫāne degül bī-üstad u bī-ṣāni‘
Lāzım gelür bir ḥakīm-i ḳādir-i pür-iḳtidār
lg.note: This workshop is not empty of a master; surely, a wise and powerful one is needed for such might.

lg.l: Vücūd-ı her masnu‘ delālet éder ‘illetine
Līk ne fāyide ki kūr degüldür ehl-i i‘tibār
lg.note: The existence of every created thing points to its cause; but what use is it, for the blind man is not a possessor of insight?

lg.l: İcdād-ı cümle-yi mevcudāt o ḳadīmdendür
Ki kemāl-i żātına olmaz nihāyet padidār
lg.note: The creation of all beings is from that Eternal One, for whose perfection of essence no end is possible.

lg.l: Oldur ḳādir u muḳtedir u ḥayy u ḳayyūm
‘Alīm u ‘allām u ḥakīm u müte‘āl
lg.note: He is the Capable, the Omnipotent, the All-Powerful, the Ordainer, and the Living; the All-Knowing, the Knower, the Infinite Knower, the Most Wise, and the Most High.
Theology: Use of Asma al-Husna (the 99 Names of God) to emphasize divine attributes.

lg.l: Ne ṣāni‘-i kāmildür ki ḳudretinden gelür
Endām-ı perī-rūlarda lutf-ı tenāsüb
lg.note: What a perfect Creator, that from His power comes the grace of proportion in the limbs of fairy-faced beauties.

lg.l: Melaḥat-ı leb-i la‘l ü ḥalāvet-i güftār
Zarafet-i ḳadd-i mevzūn u cemāl-i hūb
lg.note: The saltiness of the wine-colored lip and the sweet speech; the elegance of the well-proportioned stature and the beautiful face.

lg.l: Nezāfet-i ten-i nāzik ü ḳabūl-i żāt-ı pāk
Letāfet-i ḫaṭṭ-ı müşgīn ü zülf-i ‘anber-bār
lg.note: The purity of the graceful body and the acceptance of the pure essence; the beauty of the musk-scented down and the amber-fragrant hair.

lg.l: Silsile-yi kār-ḫāne-yi ‘ālem şāhid-i ‘adldür
Ber-kemāl-i ḳudret ü ‘ilm-i Hudā
lg.note: The links of the chain of the world's workshop are the witnesses of justice for His perfect power and knowledge.

lg.l: Vėrdi ‘anāṣır-ı basīṭe şeref-i üns-i vaḥdet
Mürekkebāta ḳabūl-i terkīb-i eczā
lg.note: He gave the honor of the intimacy of unity to the simple elements, and the acceptance of the composition of parts to the complex beings.
Cosmology: Allusion to the four elements (elements) and the synthesis of complex matter.

lg.l: Feyż alup hevā-yı cūdından bahār-ı cān-fezā
Mürebbi-yi çemen oldı nesīm-i raḥmet
lg.note: Receiving grace from the air of His generosity, the soul-refreshing spring has become the nurturer of the meadow.

lg.l: Bulup ṣaba-yı raḥmetinden feyż-i inşā
Cihānı étdi reşk-i cinān bād-ı ṣabāḥ
lg.note: Receiving the expression of bounty from the breeze of His mercy, the morning breeze has made the world the envy of paradise.

lg.l: Nüfūz étdi fażl-ı ‘āmı ṭabī‘at-ı nāmide
İstid‘ād-ı neşv ü nemāya vėrdi iḳtidār
lg.note: His all-encompassing grace has penetrated and made the growing nature ready for flourishing and growth.

lg.l: Feżā-yı gülşen-i lutfı mer‘ā-yı aḥbābdur
Meżāyıḳ-ı ḳahrı mehlika-yı eşrār
lg.note: The expanse of the rose garden of His grace is the pasture of friends; the narrow paths of His wrath are the places of destruction for enemies.

lg.l: Eger lutfı mürebbi olsa bir dāneye
Yétürür Süha’yı rütbe-yi ḫurşīde
lg.note: If His grace were to nurture even a grain for the star Suha, Suha would reach the station of equality with the Sun.
Astronomy: Suha is a very faint star in Ursa Major, used here to show Divine power to exalt the humble.

lg.l: Eger ḳahrı żāhir olsa ‘anāṣır u eflāke
Bozar ‘aḳd-i nikāḥ-ı ābā u ümmehāt
lg.note: If His wrath were to manifest upon the elements and the heavens, it would break the marriage bond between the "fathers" (planets) and "mothers" (elements).
Sufi Cosmology: Planets were considered 'fathers' (aba) and elements 'mothers' (ummehat) in the birth of minerals, plants, and animals.

lg.l: Tamām éylemişdi rızḳ-ı cemī‘-i beşeri
Henüz Ḥavvā Ādem’e peyveste olmadın
lg.note: He had completed the calculation of the sustenance for all of humanity before Eve was even joined to Adam.

lg.l: Yétmişdi beyān-ı ḥāl-i cümle-yi mahlūḳāt
Henüz esmā żevātı çekmedin ḥicāba
lg.note: The explanation of the state of all creatures was reached before names even drew the essences into the veil.

lg.l: Kemāl-i terbiyeti vėrdi ḫāra reng
Lāṭīf eyledi u adını gül-i ra‘nā ḳoydı
lg.note: The perfection of His nurturing gave color to the tip of the thorn; He made it graceful and named it "the lovely rose."

lg.l: Bıraḫdı bir avuç ḫāke āteş-i güli
Kül étdi u adını bülbül-i şeydā ḳoydı
lg.note: He cast the fire of the rose into a handful of dust on the path, turned it to ash, and named it "the frenzied nightingale."
Mystic Alchemy: The transformation of dust/earth into a longing lover (the nightingale) through divine fire.

lg.l: Şevḳ-ı vuslat-ı ḫāk-i āsitānına
Dāmen-i saḥrā elindedür du‘ā-yı baḥrıñ
lg.note: With the longing to reach the dust of His threshold, the edge of the desert is in the hand of the sea's supplication.

lg.l: Terk-i ziyāret-i ḥaremi içün seyl tīġin
Muḳarrer éyledi deryānuñ sinesine
lg.note: As a punishment for not visiting His sanctuary, He assigned the dagger of the flood to the chest of the sea.
